content:
This site is powered by my own IndieWeb-compliant publishing tool. It's my home for all my notes, articles, bookmarks, photos and more, hosted on my personal domain rather than in someone's silo. I can choose how it looks and works while having fun building it for myself.

I've been following the [principles](http://indiewebcamp.com/principles) and [recommendations](http://indiewebcamp.com/IndieMark) of the amazing [IndieWebCamp](http://indiewebcamp.com/) community who have discussed, documented and *selfdogfooded* the approaches I'm experimenting with here.

## Features

- Self-hosting using my personal, primary domain
- Posting of all my notes, articles, bookmarks, photos, replies, reposts and likes directly on my site
- [POSSE](http://indiewebcamp.com/POSSE "Publish (on your) Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere") syndication of my content to silos (e.g. Twitter) via [Bridgy](https://www.brid.gy)
- Microformats 2 markup, including [h-entry](http://microformats.org/wiki/h-entry) and [h-card](http://microformats.org/wiki/h-card)
- Send and receive replies, reposts, likes and mentions using [Webmention](http://webmention.org) with [backfeeding](http://indiewebcamp.com/backfeed) from silos
- [Reply/repost/like contexts](http://indiewebcamp.com/reply-context) fetched and displayed above posts
- Authentication via [IndieAuth](https://indieauth.com/) and `rel="me"` links
- [Micropub](http://indiewebcamp.com/micropub) posting as the primary method of creation for all post types
- [Webaction](https://indiewebcamp.com/webactions) buttons to allow actions on Twitter directly from a post
- Storage using text files in Markdown and YAML front-matter metadata

## Micropub

Rather than build an admin system for creating posts, I've attempted to do without. Instead I've exposed an API endpoint that's compliant with the (emerging) [Micropub](http://indiewebcamp.com/micropub) specification for posting using an authenticated third party app.

Using a tool like [Quill](https://quill.p3k.io) I can authenticate with [IndieAuth](https://indieauth.com/) and then post notes, bookmarks and likes to my site. A successful post is stored on my server which then fires off any webmentions, syndications to Twitter/Facebook/Pinboard and fetches reply/repost/like contexts for display if appropriate.

Alternatively I can write (or edit) a post as a file and simply `scp` or `rsync` it to my server.

## Webmentions

Instead of a comments form, my site supports replies, reposts, likes or mentions via [Webmention](http://webmention.org) from another IndieWeb site. If someone wants to respond to a post they can write their note on their own site using Microformats 2 `h-entry` markup and send a webmention ping to my endpoint.

Their `h-entry` will then be parsed, stored and added underneath my post with an icon indicating its type. Additional posts from the same permalink will update it.

And using the magic of [Bridgy](https://www.brid.gy), responses to my tweets, Facebook posts and Instagram photos that have been syndicated from my site are pulled back in as webmentions.

## Storage

All posts, webmentions and reply contexts are saved to disk as the primary method of storage. Files are then scanned, indexed and cached using [MongoDB](http://www.mongodb.org). These posts can be flushed and completely rebuilt from the raw files if needed.

Why the dual approach? I wanted the flexibility to `rsync` files to/from my server without worrying about database dumps and restores, but wanted the speed of a database to query and sort the data to serve as HTML. Also, with all content in flat text files, I'm confident that I could easily migrate to another platform.

Content is written in [Markdown](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/) format with [YAML front-matter](http://jekyllrb.com/docs/frontmatter/) metadata similar to [Jekyll](http://jekyllrb.com/). For example:

    –––
    published: "2015-01-03 23:29:11 UTC"
    permalink: "/2015/01/this-is-an-example"
    post_type: note
    tags:
    - example
    - personal
    –––
    This is an example post. **This is in bold**
    
    Another paragraph

As well as previous articles, I've imported tweets and bookmarks that I've been posting since 2004. I now have all my own content stored on my own site.

## Also

- All pages and assets are served via SSL (https)
- RSS feeds of new [posts](/index.xml) and [webmentions](/webmentions.xml)
- Auto-embedding of images and YouTube videos linked in posts
- View posts by tags, e.g. [indieweb](/tag/indieweb)
- Monthly archive index pages
- Navigate index pages using pagination

## Using

- Ruby 2.2
- [Sinatra](http://sinatrarb.com), [Webmention](https://github.com/indieweb/mention-client-ruby) and [Microformats2](https://github.com/G5/microformats2) gems
- [Unicorn](http://unicorn.bogomips.org) on [nginx](http://nginx.org)
- [MongoDB](http://www.mongodb.org)
- Ubuntu VPS on [Digital Ocean](https://www.digitalocean.com)
